citations.narrative:
Records of disposition were incomplete for some animals recently sold or transferred from the facility:
***The disposition record for two ring-tailed lemurs did not contain the address of the individual to whom the animals were
transferred on 12/2/2023.
***The disposition record for 1 red kangaroo and 4 Highland cattle did not contain the address of the individual to whom
the animals were transferred on 11/7/2023.
***The disposition record for 2 Asian small-clawed otters and 1 dromedary camel did not contain the address of the
individual to whom the animals were transferred on 12/5/2023.
***The disposition record for 5 Nilgai sold on 11/2/2023 did not contain the name or address of the person to whom the
animals were transferred.
Accurate recordkeeping is important for veterinary oversight and animal traceability in the event of disease outbreaks or
stolen animals. Correct by maintaining accurate and complete records of acquisition and disposition in accordance with
the Animal Welfare Act.

The facility's Contingency Plan is dated 11/8/2022. An annual review has not been documented since that time. Failure to
review the contingency plan annually may result in the plan becoming out of date or obsolete. Correct by reviewing the
facility's contingency plan at least once a year and by maintaining documentation of the review. Correct by: March 1,
2024.

An outdoor enclosure housing 3 ring-tailed lemurs contained two heat lamps with exposed electrical cords. At the time of
the inspection the heat lamps were on. Animals may chew on electrical cords, resulting in injury such as electrocution.
Animals may also be burned by touching heat lamps. Correct by ensuring that animals are protected from having contact
with heat lamps and electrical cords. Correct by: February 7, 2024. Corrected at the time of inspection.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The facility's enrichment plan for nonhuman primates does not address the needs of infants and young juveniles. The
facility currently has 5 ring-tailed lemurs including a breeding pair and one juvenile offspring. Primates, especially infants
and young juveniles, have complex social and environmental needs. Failure to have a plan that addresses these needs
can result in stress, poor development, and the development of abnormal behaviors. Correct by March 1, 2024 by
updating the enrichment plan in collaboration with the Attending Veterinarian to address the needs of infant and young
juvenile primates.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
At time of the inspection this facility has not documented a written plan for environmental enhancement for birds, although
they do provide enrichment for the resident birds. Birds have complex social and environmental needs, and failure to
provide for these needs may result in stress, obesity, or the development of abnormal/harmful behaviors. Dealers,
exhibitors, and research facilities must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan for environment enhancement.
The plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian and must address the social needs of birds, their environment,
and special considerations for young birds, birds showing signs of distress, and social birds housed alone. Correct by:
March 1, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1)  Repeat
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
Records of disposition were incomplete for some animals recently sold or transferred from the facility: 
***The disposition record for two ring-tailed lemurs did not contain the address of the individual to whom the animals were 
transferred on 12/2/2023.  
***The disposition record for 1 red kangaroo and 4 Highland cattle did not contain the address of the individual to whom 
the animals were transferred on 11/7/2023. 
***The disposition record for 2 Asian small-clawed otters and 1 dromedary camel did not contain the address of the 
individual to whom the animals were transferred on 12/5/2023. 
***The disposition record for 5 Nilgai sold on 11/2/2023 did not contain the name or address of the person to whom the 
animals were transferred. 
Accurate recordkeeping is important for veterinary oversight and animal traceability in the event of disease outbreaks or 
stolen animals. Correct by maintaining accurate and complete records of acquisition and disposition in accordance with 
the Animal Welfare Act. 
2.134(b) 
   
Contingency planning. 
The facility's Contingency Plan is dated 11/8/2022. An annual review has not been documented since that time. Failure to 
review the contingency plan annually may result in the plan becoming out of date or obsolete. Correct by reviewing the 
facility's contingency plan at least once a year and by maintaining documentation of the review. Correct by: March 1, 
2024. 
3.80(a)(2)(ii) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
An outdoor enclosure housing 3 ring-tailed lemurs contained two heat lamps with exposed electrical cords. At the time of 
the inspection the heat lamps were on. Animals may chew on electrical cords, resulting in injury such as electrocution. 
Animals may also be burned by touching heat lamps. Correct by ensuring that animals are protected from having contact 
with heat lamps and electrical cords. Correct by: February 7, 2024. Corrected at the time of inspection. 
3.81(c)(1)

Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The facility's enrichment plan for nonhuman primates does not address the needs of infants and young juveniles. The 
facility currently has 5 ring-tailed lemurs including a breeding pair and one juvenile offspring. Primates, especially infants 
and young juveniles, have complex social and environmental needs. Failure to have a plan that addresses these needs 
can result in stress, poor development, and the development of abnormal behaviors. Correct by March 1, 2024 by 
updating the enrichment plan in collaboration with the Attending Veterinarian to address the needs of infant and young 
juvenile primates. 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
At time of the inspection this facility has not documented a written plan for environmental enhancement for birds, although 
they do provide enrichment for the resident birds. Birds have complex social and environmental needs, and failure to 
provide for these needs may result in stress, obesity, or the development of abnormal/harmful behaviors. Dealers, 
exhibitors, and research facilities must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan for environment enhancement. 
The plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian and must address the social needs of birds, their environment, 
and special considerations for young birds, birds showing signs of distress, and social birds housed alone. Correct by: 
March 1, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
